title: Pacific Ocean garbage patch is immense plastic habitat - BBC
body: Dr Haram worked with the Ocean Voyages Institute, a charity that collects plastic pollution on sailing expeditions, and with oceanographers from the University of Hawaii at Manoa. The Ocean Cleanup
readable_content:
- BBC News (2023-12-08): Scientists have discovered marine animals living on plastic debris in an area of the open ocean dubbed "the Great Pacific Garbage Patch." Many of the creatures are coastal species, living miles from their usual habitats, on a patch halfway between the coast of California and Hawaii. The study examined plastic items more than 5cm (2in) in diameter gathered from a gyre in the Pacific, and found plants and animals, including anemones, marine bugs, molluscs, and crabs on 90% of the debris. Scientists are concerned about plastic aiding the transport of invasive species, and highlighted the unintended consequence of plastic pollution. This discovery underscores a problem that is expected to grow, with an estimated 25,000 million tonnes of plastic waste being generated by 2050.

summary: The article discusses the concerning discovery of marine animals living on plastic debris in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, highlighting the unintended consequences of plastic pollution. Scientists are worried about the potential transport of invasive species and the growing problem of plastic waste. This emphasizes the urgent need to address plastic pollution. Sentiment: 0.8
